all_paragraphs: Just as electricity transformed almost everything 100 years ago, today I actually have a hard time thinking of an industry that I don’t think AI (Artificial Intelligence) will transform in the next several years.” ~Andrew Ng
Machine learning is always paramount to become a successful data scientists and analysts. Through machine learning, we learnt how to run procedures to turn raw data into insights and predictions.
However, when you begin your analysis on a certain case, where would you start?

In this article, I would like to write about ML toolbox to get you started exploring with ML in a new dataset. ML is an iterative process; most of the time, you will need to go iterate through the business problems to refine your ML operations.

I sincerely hope that this article can be a starting point to run your initial explorations on any dataset. I also created Data Visualization Toolbox based on my experience and recurring exploration that helps you kickstart your data projects.
These are recurring code snippets that personal repeated over my data explorations at Google and Visa — my toolbox for quick and dirty ML Exploratory.
By the end of this article, you should implement these codes and run initial iterations of ML exploration. You can follow these steps and extract insights.
The following are the flow of initial exploration:
For this scenario, we will use HR Retention Dataset which simulates a typical classification objective.
who’s going to quit your company

For those of you who do not know Seaborn, shame on me for not telling you sooner. In my opinion, this is one of the biggest treasures that every data analyst and scientist needs to be familiar with! (no joke!).
Seaborn will allow you to create stunning graph and visualizations within seconds. Thus, a very important tool to brush up your storytelling techniques as effective data scientists/analysts.
Seaborn is a Python data visualization library based on matplotlib. It provides a high-level interface for drawing attractive and informative statistical graphics. — Seaborn Pydata Org
Scikit Learn (SkLearn) is a ML library for python. It has modularized functionalities that you need to run various ML features such as classification, clustering, and regression.
SkLearn operates with Python Scientific Libraries such as NumPy and SciPy and support algorithms such as SVM (Support Vector Machine), Decision Tree, and Logistic Regression.
For this tutorial, we will focus on Decision Tree and Logistic Regression as they provide intuitive visual representation and easy implementation. Most of the time, they are “good” enough.

I always recommend, SkLearn, Matplotlib and Seaborn to get >80% typical data visualization done. If you use Colab, these libraries are all ready for you. If don’t, run the following on your packet manager.

Imagine you have a feature “university_names” which included labels such as “Harvard” , “Georgia Tech”, “National University of Singapore”, etc. How are you representing them for distance based ML such as logistic regression and K Nearest Neighbor (KNN)?
When you have a categorical variable (non numerical), You will need to create multiple dummy features to replace categorical into numerical features.

Dummification removed encoded variables and add unique integer value to is_[feature] variable (e.g: is_harvard_graduate, is_yale_graduate). These are represented with 0 (False) or 1 (True) which is used for distance based ML.
You should use this when… you use categorical target variables for Regression/distance based ML.

Imagine HR Retention problem in a small startups. You are responsible to predict who are leaving your company. You collected all of the data you can think of: their family background, their job histories, and performance over last 1 year.
You are happy because you have 100+ features and felt sufficient to feed them into Neural Network.

This a trap for the curse of dimensionality (Richard E. Bellman). In fact, when you have a wide dataset but short datasets (large n_features but low data size). It is very easy to overfit your ML model because it will memorize all of the observations given unique feature sets.
The solution is to reduce your feature sets size. This allows the model to ignore irrelevant features and learn relevant features.
We use a simple algorithm called Recursive Feature Elimination (RFE). This method reruns the filtering of the features one by one until the set is redeemed the one to give the best learnability.

Imagine your school basketball club. Each year, the coach gathers interested students and eliminate a few in each playoff. The end result is a set of players with consistent skills and teamwork to perform.
You rank the feature set based on how important they are in a set.
You should use this when… there are wide features with low observations with a tendency to overfit your ML model.

Imagine your last academic exams. How did you prepare? Did you memorize all mock exams answers but not perform well in the final exam? If yes, you need to understand your mock exams (train) to produce results on the final exams (test).
Splitting the training and testing dataset is important to evaluate the ability of model to accurately represent reality.
It is a litmus test we use to know if the model underfit or overfit.
You should use this when… You evaluate any ML Model.
Imagine your current colleagues in the office. Could you choose 3 people that most likely to leave small startups?
How about if I showed you who perform well based on the last 1 year? Can you guess better?
Logistic Regression is a probability based model which uses the maximum likelihood as the distance functions. It calculates the probability to predict a certain value given an input.
In my opinion, one of the best use case is to identify proper weights. They best explain the weights of feature X which is handy for scoring based detection system (credit risk or flight risk).
Caveat: watch out for morality issues (read Weapons of Math Destruction)
In the result below. We observe that satisfaction_result,work_accident, and salary level have heavy weights to predict employee flight risks.
You should use this when… You run regression based model, analyse its coefficients, and predict classification problems.
The goal of Decision Tree is to split data into groups which maximize information gain.
The biggest advantage of Decision Tree is the intuition and easiness to derive insights even with uncleaned and unnormalized data. It is unfazed by outliers and split top features with rules.
In my opinion, its best usecase is to find profiles that best explain a certain class. For example, the symptoms of leaving employees are: low_satisfaction and low_last_evaluation.
You should use this when… You run rule based model, analyse its rules for class profiling, and predict classification problems.
Confusion metrics compare model prediction to reality which allows us to understand the model performances and answer business problems — Data School:
You should use this when… You evaluate any model for classification problems.

AUC (Area Under Curve) — ROC (Optimal Curve) sets threshold in setting simulations to measure confidence in the classification verdicts. It tells how much the model is able to distinguish the class by giving a percentage.
The higher the AUC, the better the model confidently predict. Logically for medical and high risk environments, you want to have AUC to be high to show high confidence in every verdict
While in email spam detections, such high standards might not be necessary.
You should use this when… You analyse models for classification problems and identify confidence before rolling your model to production.

I believe these codes are simple to implement straight away in your first data exploration. This visualization toolbox will give you the head start you need to become more confident in exploring and visualizing your data.
